body: @rdblue @xabriel @prodeezy . I've updated the PR. Tests still need more work. I haven't added tests for rollbacks and transactions as @rdblue  wants. I plan to do this in a couple of days, but sending out the updated approach early for feedback
I'll merge this since @aokolnychyi had a look and there's just a minor style issue with it.

@andrei-ionescu, this hasn't been updated to handle Avro and Parquet differently. This changes Parquet to use partition values from each DataFile, but it does not update Avro (or ORC). That's why Avro needs to use the same logic as before, with a joined row. This should also test that reading a data file without the partition columns works for both Avro and Parquet.

@rdblue, 

I don’t fully understand what you mean and what you’re asking. I added a test that uses Avro as the underlying store format and it works very well without any changes. What’s the case/test that require the change back to joining rows?

I’ll add the test for Avro without any partitions as you suggest.

I guess I’m missing something that you are aware of and that is why I need more information.

@chenjunjiedada, I've made most of the requested changes and opened a PR against your branch: https://github.com/chenjunjiedada/incubator-iceberg/pull/4

I'm still working on some of the tests that are failing.
@rdblue Thanks for the code review. I have updated the PR accordingly.
Added an initial PR for review: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/695
@rdblue, we do support row group skipping for predicates on decimal columns, don't we?
@jerryshao @rdblue @prodeezy  Many thanks for your valuable comments. I just back from vacation and will update the pull request ASAP.

@rdblue:
> We could do the same thing with snapshot IDs for time-travel, like db.table.982135791981.

Current time-travel Spark API uses options:
```
spark.read
    .format("iceberg")
    .option("snapshot-id", 10963874102873L)
    .load("db.table")
```
https://iceberg.apache.org/spark/#time-travel

For consistency, should we continue building on top of that pattern and perhaps do something like this?
```
spark.read
    .format("iceberg")
    .option("appends-between", "1234..1235") // or "1234..current" for appendsAfter
    .load("db.table")
```

@chenjunjiedada, I merged this into the branch for Spark 3.0 along with the updates from my PR against your branch: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/commits/spark-3

I'll close this PR.
@rdblue, OK, I will rebase my local branches.
@rdblue Sure I can open up a PR to extend DataTest and fix those issues after this PR is in.
HI， @rdblue , Please give me some advice when you are convenient thanks.
HI， @rdblue  , Please give me some advice when you are convenient thanks.
@rdblue The CI finally passed 👍

@xabriel, I think that makes sense for the dataframe API, but I think it is important to have a way to time-travel in the SQL API as well. That's why I'm interested in what we can do with Spark's multi-part identifiers.
@rdblue @aokolnychyi  Please take a look. This is a first cut implementation with appends only. Initial implementation submission for feedback.

After talking with @samarthjain, it sounds like the reason why Spark classes are in the Arrow module is because we still need to refactor to separate the Parquet/Arrow code from the Arrow/Spark code. Since this blocks testing without recompiling Spark, I'll go ahead and merge it into the vectorized read branch and we can fix the problems in the refactor or before merging to master.

Thanks @prodeezy!
+1 LGTM.

Iceberg doesn't currently support pushing down predicates because it can't translate from BigDecimal into predicates on Parquet primitives.

Parquet stats were also incorrect for decimals stored as Binary, but in that case the stats are suppressed so it is safe to push down the predicates. I think we just need to add the translation for int and long decimal storage, and a comparator for binary decimals.
Thanks, @aokolnychyi!
Thanks, @chenjunjiedada! I merged this.

Thanks @rdblue and @moulimukherjee for the code review!
Fixed the problems and added more tests.
@bryanck @rdblue, Reviewing this PR actually made me wonder whether we get any benefits from using a thread pool in `BaseRewriteManifests` as `Writer` methods are synchronized.
@rdblue @xabriel @prodeezy . I think this is ready for another round of review.

thanks @aokolnychyi  very good point. 
I was also wondering that before raising this PR, but then thought if we want to discuss and take care of `synchronized` as a separate issue/PR.
@rdblue it would be helpful, if you review this. thanks !
https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/issues/311 and https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/702 address this issue. Can close this? @rdblue @samarthjain @anjalinorwood
Closing. Thanks @prodeezy and @samarthjain!
@chenjunjiedada & @jerryshao, this PR adds a session catalog that can handle both Iceberg and Hive tables in the same namespace.
LGTM +1

I think we want to avoid requiring a custom registrator for Spark to work with Kryo. Instead, we will need to use non-guava collections in places that may be serialized with Kryo.

@jzhuge, @aokolnychyi, should we close this or is there still value in having a custom registrator even if we try to avoid needing it?

@andrei-ionescu, this PR changes the way partition values are added to result records for Parquet. It does not change Avro or ORC. That means that the changes in Reader that remove the `JoinedRow` should not be applied to Avro or ORC. This PR needs to make changes just to the Parquet read, not for Avro or ORC.
Ok to close.

I don't think it is a good idea to store namespace metadata like this for the Hadoop catalog. There isn't a good way to ensure that only one writer changes the namespace metadata file at a time. That means concurrent changes could clobber one another, which would cause the metadata to get out of date. Since this metadata is an optimization and not a source of truth, that is a serious correctness problem.

Because the source of truth for a Hadoop catalog is what is in the file system, I think Hadoop catalogs should continue to use FS listing to guarantee that results are correct.
Thanks @cdw9bf! I merged this.
Thanks @rdsr! Looks great.
Thanks @shawnding! I think we should get #688 in first and then port it to the Spark 3 branch.
Merged. Thanks @shawnding!

@rdsr, thanks for picking this up. Do you want to submit a PR to replace this one? I'm going to close this since it hasn't been updated.

@fbocse, feel free to reopen this if you want to work on it.
Thanks for all of the work on this, @cmathiesen! It looks helpful, although I'd like to make a few changes to make sure it uses best practices.

I'm not sure that we will want to do this. Iceberg doesn't currently support this because it doesn't get locality information before planning splits. Split planning is handled entirely with Iceberg metadata.

We could add locality by looking up the locality of files in a split, or by providing a method that lazily loads locality information. But both of those options will require remote calls to HDFS, so it would be very expensive.
I'm not sure what Beam I/O is because I'm not familiar with Beam. Can you explain what it is? Sounds like integration; should that be located in Beam instead of Iceberg?
It's difficult to understand what you're trying to do from the information provided. I recommend looking at logs to find out what predicates were applied to your table scans.
Fixed by #681.
Looks like `checkCompatibility` needs to be updated to throw an exception with a better error message when a column is not present. @pprudhvi, would you like to submit a PR to fix this?
Looks like the actual cause is missing from the originally reported stack trace. The later trace with the block fetch failure might be the problem, but it's hard to tell what's going on there.
@jun-he, can you rebase and fix the conflicts? #686 was merged, which probably caused them. That also added the comparator method you needed.
Looks like this has a conflict now. Could you fix it and I'll review again?
@rdblue thanks. I'll submit a PR soon
OK i split it for two PR

What we did internally is to trigger RPC calls to get block information. Yes, there's overhead to trigger RPC calls, but I think this is a trade-off between locality and split planning. In object store like S3, locality may not be so important and to get block information has big overhead, but for HDFS, it may not be so big. So I think we may provide a conf to report locality information or not, and turn it off by default.

~~yes, I can submit a patch but it won't fix the issue with dropping a partition colum. Or~~ this was already put in place with [#532](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/532). Do we need to follow a different path to drop such columns - update partition spec first and then call deleteColumn ?
Nice PR!  Do we still need to support namespace in `SparkCatalog`?

My one concern is that if we share the same hive metastore between Iceberg catalog and Spark session catalog, will there be some unexpected behaviors for drop, rename and alter tables? Because both two catalogs can see other's meta info, but the meta infos are different, so for example, Iceberg catalog can drop Hive table, will this lead to some unexpected behaviors?

Thanks @rdblue , I understand the intent, my simple concern is that because we don't check whether it is iceberg table or just hive table in some catalog methods, so it may have a chance to use iceberg catalog to drop hive table.

@jerryshao , The `icebergCatalog.tableExists(ident)` is used to determine whether a table is iceberg table or not in `renameTable` and `alterTable`.

@rdblue, The `dropTable` doesn't check it, does that means it is OK to drop a hive table via iceberg hive catalog?

@chenjunjiedada, Catalogs throw NotIcebergException (extends NoSuchTableException) if a table is not Iceberg, so Iceberg won't try to delete a non-Iceberg table. In the case of drop, when the table is not Iceberg or is missing, the method returns false. That's why we don't use try/catch: the exception is not thrown because throwing it would violate the method contract.

@jerryshao, that's why I updated the methods. This now checks that the table is Iceberg, or relies on the method contract as I explained above for drop.
LGTM +1
@rdblue Would you please share your opinions here at your most convenience?
Thanks for looking at this, @jerryshao and @chenjunjiedada!

Would using `./test` work to clarify?

I think that the current behavior is correct. Hive tables should be the default when there is a conflict because there are easy ways to modify the path to indicate a Hadoop table (like `./test`).

This shouldn't remove characters. It assumes that there is no identifier quoting. If we plan to support identifier quoting, then we should parse identifiers correctly using Spark's parser or with an internal one that has the same behavior.

I think it would be better to catch this while updating the schema, rather than after running the schema update and trying to commit it. That way, `UpdateSchema.apply` will also catch the failure.

Can you add precondition checks to `UpdateSchema.deleteColumn`? And tests should be added to `TestSchemaUpdate`.
@manishmalhotrawork, I've added review comments. Sorry I wasn't able to get back to this sooner!
Thanks for working on this @manishmalhotrawork! It looks pretty close to me.
@rdblue  Done. Can you please take a look? Thanks.
@rdblue  Done. Can you please take a look? Thanks.
I think we should use `sparkSession.sessionState.sqlParser.parseMultipartIdentifier` to get the correct Identifier.

By revisiting the code, I found that most of the operations has cleanup methods `cleanUncommitted`, `cleanAll` after commit is failed, so seems there's no need to implement `abortStagedChanges`, what's your opinion @rdblue?
HI Ryan, I had add precondition checks to UpdateSchema.deleteColumn.  Because  the table spec should base on the table not only schema, so I Add the test util in HiveTableTest.java
@aokolnychyi are you currently working on this feature? IIUC this seems depends on #315 .
Any specific reason to choose `(a, b]` instead of `[a, b)`?

Hi @rdblue, thanks for sharing your idea! 
How about making it more strict: when the path prefixes with "/", "./", "../", or [a hierarchical URI](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/net/URI.html), it routes to Hadoop table, otherwise, it is routed to Hive table. Make sense to you? An initial PR is submitted as https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/719
Thanks @Fokko!

@shawnding, I'm not sure I understand your rationale for adding the test to HiveTableTest.

At a minimum, this should be a new test case and should not alter an unrelated test. It's okay to have a new test case in HiveTableTest, but i don't think this needs to modify the test base. Also, this needs to be tested in `TestSchemaUpdate`.

@shawnding, I've noticed that you've missed several review comments, like removing unnecessary `toString` calls when concatenating strings or formatting error messages. Please go back through the review comments to make sure you've made all of the needed changes. It's not very fun to ask for the same changes each time I take a look at this PR. Thanks!
Merged! Thanks for getting this done, @jun-he!
Thanks for getting this done, @jun-he! Nice work.

Thanks for all your work on this, @yathindranath! I've merged it.

Also, thanks for being patient while I was behind on code reviews. Sorry about the delay getting your work into master.

@rdsr, this looks great! The main things I'd like to change are rolling back the addition to `ManifestReader` and moving the `appendsBetween` methods to `TableScan` with a default implementation that throws `UnsupportedOperationException`.

Is anyone still interested in moving this forward? I think it makes sense to allow paths to be relative to the table location, but not to add paths that are relative to manifest files. I think that's too much complexity just to avoid some manifest rewriting.
Since it's been a while, I'm going to close this PR. Feel free to reopen if you'd like to discuss this more.

@jerryshao, are you looking up each file status individually? Is there a bulk API that we can use?

I'm +1 for having a flag to turn it on and off. We can also default based on a white list of locality file systems, like HDFS.
@pprudhvi, I think #716 is going to add a nice error message for this. #532 added a check to the validation, but that error message was confusing.
#714 tracks the error message, and #532 fixed the NPE this reported so I'm going to close this.

Yes, `sortWithinPartitions` won't work, but you should be able to `repartition` by your partition columns, right?

@aokolnychyi and I have also talked about relaxing this constraint for Spark streaming and keeping multiple files open.

@yujiantao, the current fallback strategy for assigning IDs assumes that your data has not had any columns removed. We've talked about adding support for `NameMapping` to Parquet so that it will fall back to name-based resolution. We've built this for Avro since Avro only supports name-based resolution (Parquet supports both name-based and position-based in some systems).

Would you like to work on adding an ID assignment fallback implementation that uses `NameMapping`?

@jerryshao, I think that we do need to implement the abort method. The abort is called if there is any failure with the final commit (see https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/datasources/v2/WriteToDataSourceV2Exec.scala#L494).

That commit happens after the write operation has committed to the transaction, so Spark is no longer responsible for calling the writer's abort methods with each task's commit data. If the transaction has a successful write committed, then Spark won't clean up the data files that were created and Iceberg should. It's a narrow case, where the write succeeds and Iceberg's commit fails, but we should plan on handling it. Because it is such a narrow case, I didn't think it was very urgent.
Yes, repartition works, but it feels like it’s a extra work to workaround the constraint.
Currently we're looking up each file status individually, I'm not sure if there's bulk APIs we can use, let me search it.
LGTM +1
@samarthjain, thanks for fixing this! The remaining changes are minor so I merged this and we can fix them in a follow-up.
Thanks for looking into it more, @waterlx! I'm going to close this since you say it doesn't seem necessary to make these changes.
Thanks for reviewing, @chenjunjiedada and @jerryshao!
